title: Can I use samples of classical music recordings in my music without facing legal complications? - Quora
tags: Legal Issues and Law in Everyday Life

response.answer_text: We need to be very careful of the difference between samples and examples. If you mean sampling in the technical sense of using a clip of somebody else’s recording and incorporating a recording of that clip in your own piece, then no. Someone will own the rights to that recording - the record company, possibly the conductor and orchestra who performed it. And in the case of opera or choral work, living singers who would have strong views about their work being sampled and used for a different performance. You can use out-of-copyright music. Provided it is an original performance, by you or by musicians you have contracted for the recording/performance. That will not mean all “classical music”. In most jurisdictions copyright lasts until 70 years after the composer’s death. William Walton’s music is copyrighted until 2053. Benjamin Britten until 2046. Richard Strauss (“Also Sprach Zarathustra” etc) was copyrighted until last September…

To use a sample legally, you need two separate licenses: one for the audio recording itself, and one for the underlying composition. All the canonical masterpieces from before 1900 are in the public domain, so you’d be fine as far as the underlying composition goes. But you still have to negotiate a license with the owner of the recording that you’re sampling (typically the record label, Sony Classical or Deutsche Grammophon or whoever it is.)

Yes if you perform them yourself and make you’re own recording, providing the piece is no longer under copyright protection which is 70 years though could be 75 years. You cannot use a pre-existing recording though, even if the music copyright is long over like for any Bach or Mozart piece.
Not without permission. Almost almost all audio recordings are still under copyright. It doesn’t matter what the music on them is.
